OFFICERS. The State Administrator will establish a Problem Resolution Office where officers can investigate taxpayer complaints and stop collection activities if they are likely not compliant with the law. Only the highest official in the relevant taxing authority can reverse this decision with clear evidence, and officers cannot be penalized for their actions. Officers will not face discipline for issuing administrative injunctions unless a pattern of unreasonable injunctions is proven. State Administrators and taxpayers retain the right to pursue legal remedies in court. SEC. 53. JURISDICTION AND INTERSTATE ALLOCATION. Allocation Rules: Revenue from taxes imposed by this subtitle will be allocated to states based on the destination of taxable property or services. The Secretary will establish an Office of Revenue Allocation to resolve disputes among states regarding revenue allocation. The Administrator of the Office of Revenue Allocation determines the destination of tangible personal property for tax purposes. Tangible personal property is deemed delivered to the purchaser's location upon shipment by mail or common carrier. The destination of real property or rents/leaseholds on real property is the state where the property is located. For other property, the destination is the purchaser's residence. Services are allocated based on where they are used, consumed, or enjoyed, with telecommunications services having specific destination rules. Telecommunications services are allocated based on the purchaser's residence, including telephone, telegraph, cable television, satellite, and computer services. Domestic transportation services are allocated based on the final destination within the United States. Financial intermediation services are allocated based on the purchaser's residence. A State Tax Administrator has jurisdiction over gross payments with a destination within the state. International transportation services have 50 percent attributed to the United States destination or origin. The State Tax Administrator has jurisdiction over gross payments with a destination within the state, which is not exclusive. Rents and royalties for tangible property are allocated based on the property's location. Rent and lease payments for vehicles are determined by the location where the vehicle was originally delivered to the lessee. Rent and lease payments for vehicles are determined by the location where the vehicle was originally delivered to the lessee, and for rentals and leases of a term greater than one month, the residence of the lessee. SEC. 54. TAX TO BE STATED AND CHARGED SEPARATELY. The sales tax must be charged separately from the purchase price by the vendor. A receipt provided to the purchaser should include the property or services price exclusive of tax, the amount of tax paid, the property or service price inclusive of tax, and the tax rate. The requirements for sales tax include the date of sale, vendor name, and registration number. Sales by vending machines are exempt from these requirements if they dispense taxable items for coins or bills up to $20, with no single item exceeding $10. The State Administrator or Secretary can enter installment agreements with taxpayers to pay taxes in installments, and may compromise on amounts due. SEC. 56. ACCOUNTING. Vendors and persons must remit taxes based on when payment is received or when the tax is due. An election can be made to use the accrual method for reporting transactions. For bad debts under the accrual method, refer to section 11(g).

SEC. 57. HOBBY ACTIVITIES. SEC. 57. HOBBY ACTIVITIES. The exemption for non-profit trade or business is not available for taxable property or services. If gross payments exceed certain criteria in 2 of the last 4 years, the business is deemed for profit. (a) Appropriations for expenses of the Internal Revenue Service, including processing income tax returns, revenue accounting, and payroll tax data transfer, are not authorized for years after fiscal year 2001.
(b) Section 7801 is amended to establish an Excise Tax Bureau and a Sales Tax Bureau within the Department of Treasury. The Treasury establishes a Sales Tax Bureau to administer the national sales tax in required States and fulfill Federal duties related to the tax. The Secretary of the Treasury can appoint up to 5 Assistant General Counsels without following civil service laws. A short year is defined for Federal income tax purposes. For Federal income tax purposes, a short year is defined as modifying the tax imposed for taxable years ending June 30, 1999. Dollar figures in section 1 and section 11 are adjusted for calendar year and fiscal year taxpayers. The Secretary will publish tax rate schedules based on the ratio of months in the taxpayer's taxable year ending June 30, 1999, to 12. The Social Security Administration will collect payroll taxes starting January 1, 1999. This includes self-employment income taxes and employment taxes. Section 7 of the Act covers revised rules for self-employment tax. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to define 'self-employment income' as gross payments received in a calendar year from the sale of taxable property or services, minus purchases of taxable property or services, wages paid for business purposes, unused transition amounts, and undeducted negative self-employment income from prior periods. The transition amount for the ten calendar years starting in 1999 is calculated as the unrecovered basis amount as of December 31, 1998 divided by ten. The unrecovered basis amount includes remaining income tax basis related to prior law section 167 property and inventory held at the end of 1998. The transition amount for the ten calendar years starting in 1999 is calculated as the unrecovered basis amount as of December 31, 1998 divided by ten, including any amounts capitalized in accordance with prior law section 263A. Conforming Amendments are made to subsections 1402(b) and 1402(c), with subsections 1402(d) et seq. being renumbered as subsections 1402(b) et seq. SOCIAL SECURITY BENEFITS INDEXED ON SALES TAX INCLUSIVE BASIS. The Consumer Price Index for Social Security benefits is amended to calculate the CPI increase percentage for cost-of-living adjustments. The Consumer Price Index for Social Security benefits is amended to calculate the CPI increase percentage for cost-of-living adjustments based on the national sales tax factor. The national sales tax factor is determined by the sales tax rate divided by one minus the sales tax rate, and is used to calculate the Consumer Price Index increase percentage for cost-of-living adjustments. SEC. 9. COMPENSATING PAYMENTS TO CERTAIN PERSONS ON FIXED INCOME. Compensating Payment: Eligible persons receive a compensating payment if they comply with the application requirements. The payment is calculated based on the qualified fixed income payment amount and the excess inflation rate. An eligible person is someone who receives Social Security benefits and qualified fixed income payments. A qualified fixed income payment is a payment received by a beneficiary under a defined benefit plan or by an annuitant pursuant to an annuity contract with a bona fide insurance company. Payments that vary with investment performance are not considered qualified fixed income payments. The qualified fixed income payment amount is \1/12\ of payments entitled to an eligible person during the calendar year, excluding payments from annuity contracts entered into after June 30, 1999, and defined benefit plans for beneficiaries with less than 5 years of participation. An eligible person is entitled to receive a qualified fixed income payment amount not exceeding $5,000 in the calendar year following the year for which the compensating payment is calculated. The excess inflation rate is defined as the difference between the consumer price index (all urban) during an 18-month period ending December 31, 2000, and the projected increase in the consumer price index reported in the Budget of the United States for Fiscal Year 1999. The baseline assumption for compensating payments in 1999 is half of the assumed increase for the entire year. Eligible individuals must apply for compensating payments as prescribed by the Secretary of Health and Human Services. Compensating payments will be received with Social Security benefits, funded by the general fund. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may require insurers and defined benefit plan sponsors to issue a statement to annuitants or plan participants for compensating payments, funded by the general fund. SEC. 10 amends the Internal Revenue Code by adjusting interest rates. SEC. 11 requires a supermajority to raise rates. SEC. 11 requires a supermajority vote in the House of Representatives or the Senate to consider any bill that increases federal sales tax rates or reduces federal revenues through exemptions or benefits. The waiver or suspension of this requirement can only be done by a two-thirds affirmative vote.
